meta.content: A direct numerical simulation of a fully developed turbulent Couette-Poiseuille flow with a rod-roughened wall is performed to investigate the impact of the surface roughness on the flow characteristics compared to the influence of the roughness on a turbulent Poiseuille flow. Transverse rods are periodically arranged on the bottom wall with a streamwise pitch of p = 8k. The roughness height is k = 0.12h, where h is the channel half-height. The mean velocity profile shows that the logarithmic layer of a turbulent Couette-Poiseuille flow is significantly shortened by surface roughness, although that of a turbulent Poiseuille flow with surface roughness is increased. In addition, the Reynolds stresses for the Couette-Poiseuille flow with rod roughness are decreased in the outer layer, contrary to the observation of a turbulent Poiseuille flow with rod roughness. The decomposition of the Reynolds stresses into small- and large-scale motions confirms that the large-scale features dominantly contribute to the decrease of the Reynolds stresses in the outer layer. Although a large-scale counter-rotating roll mode is observed through temporally averaged streamwise fluctuating structures, the roll mode for the Couette-Poiseuille flow over a rough wall is significantly inhibited by the surface roughness due to weakened high- and low-streaky patterns near the centerline. The energy spectrum of the streamwise velocity fluctuations shows that the surface roughness contributes mainly to organizing the entire flow field; thus, the large-scale features observed in a turbulent Couette-Poiseuille flow are significantly suppressed with little interaction between the inner and outer layers.

A direct numerical simulation of a fully developed turbulent Couette-Poiseuille flow with a rod-roughened wall is performed to investigate the impact of the surface roughness on the flow characteristics compared to the influence of the roughness on a turbulent Poiseuille flow. Transverse rods are periodically arranged on the bottom wall with a streamwise pitch of
p
= 8
k

k
= 0.12
h
, where
h
is the channel half-height. The mean velocity profile shows that the logarithmic layer of a turbulent Couette-Poiseuille flow is significantly shortened by surface roughness, although that of a turbulent Poiseuille flow with surface roughness is increased. In addition, the Reynolds stresses for the Couette-Poiseuille flow with rod roughness are decreased in the outer layer, contrary to the observation of a turbulent Poiseuille flow with rod roughness. The decomposition of the Reynolds stresses into small- and large-scale motions confirms that the large-scale features dominantly contribute to the decrease of the Reynolds stresses in the outer layer. Although a large-scale counter-rotating roll mode is observed through temporally averaged streamwise fluctuating structures, the roll mode for the Couette-Poiseuille flow over a rough wall is significantly inhibited by the surface roughness due to weakened high- and low-streaky patterns near the centerline. The energy spectrum of the streamwise velocity fluctuations shows that the surface roughness contributes mainly to organizing the entire flow field; thus, the large-scale features observed in a turbulent Couette-Poiseuille flow are significantly suppressed with little interaction between the inner and outer layers.

IV. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSION
Section:

In the present study, we undertook a DNS of a turbulent plane Couette-Poiseuille flow with a rod-roughened wall (CR-type) to examine modifications of the flow characteristics by surface roughness and compared these results with those of a turbulent Poiseuille flow with rod roughness (PR-type). Although the logarithmic layer for the PR-type is elongated further from the wall than that for a turbulent Poiseuille flow with a smooth wall (P-type), the wall-normal extent of the logarithmic layer for the CR-type is significantly shortened compared to that for a turbulent Couette-Poiseuille flow with a smooth wall (C-type). Similar values of the von KÃ¡rmÃ¡n constant (
Îº
= 0.39) for the PR-type and the CR-type were observed, and the roughness function for the CR-type was smaller than that for the PR-type, resulting in less impact of the roughness on the flow for the CR-type (as evidenced by
k
s
). The introduction of surface roughness on the P-type led to an increase in the Reynolds stress in the outer layer. However, the magnitude of the Reynolds stress for the CR-type was decreased in the outer layer compared to that for the C-type, and the quadrant analysis of the Reynolds shear stress suggested that the decreased Reynolds shear stress mainly comes from the reduction of the fourth-quadrant Q4 event motions in the outer layer. Furthermore, an analysis of the turbulence energy production showed that it is a combination of the reduced mean shear and Reynolds shear stress, leading to a decrease of the Reynolds stress in the outer layer for the CR-type. Consistent with the observation for the PR-type, the profiles of the Reynolds anisotropic tensor for the CR-type indicated that turbulent energy is significantly transferred from the streamwise component to the wall-normal and spanwise components in the near-wall region and that the energy transfer in the outer layer occurs in the opposite direction. The scale decomposition of the Reynolds stress into small- and large-scale motions revealed that the influence of the surface roughness on the outer region for the CR-type is mostly attributed to the weakening effects of the large-scale features. Because it is known that low-speed streaks generate large-scale vortices according to a regeneration mechanism in the core region, the weakened streaky patterns near the centerline for the CR-type led to the suppression of the counter-rotating large-scale vortices, resulting in a reduction of the Reynolds shear stress in the outer layer. The inhibited outer-region large-scale features for the CR-type were confirmed in energy spectrum maps of the streamwise velocity fluctuations with only a scant spectral footprint in the near-wall region.
